"Groundhog Day", starring the charismatic Bill Murray, follows a weatherman trapped in a time loop who eventually learns valuable life lessons. On the other hand, "Rain Man", featuring memorable performances by Dustin Hoffman and Tom Cruise, tells the story of two brothers discovering each other after years apart, with one brother having autism-savant abilities. Both films offer thoughtful explorations of identity and personal growth within unique circumstances.

It seems like you're interested in war films with a strong narrative, so I'd recommend "Born on the Fourth of July" and "Doctor Zhivago".

"Born on the Fourth of July" is a powerful biographical drama about Ron Kovic, a soldier who becomes an anti-war activist after his experiences in Vietnam. It stars Tom Cruise and features a compelling performance from Oliver Stone as the director.

"Doctor Zhivago", set during World War I and the October Revolution, tells the life story of a Russian physician and poet. This epic film boasts an impressive cast including Julie Christie, Hugh Bonneville, and Keira Knightley.

Given that you were expecting a different vibe and mentioned a preference for war genre films, I'd recommend "War Horse" and "Patriot Games".

"War Horse", based on Michael Morpurgo's novel, is an extraordinary journey set during World War I, featuring stunning visual effects and a powerful story of friendship between a horse and his owner.

As for "Patriot Games", this film stars Harrison Ford as CIA analyst Jack Ryan who finds himself targeted by a renegade faction after interfering with an IRA assassination, creating a high-stakes cat-and-mouse game. Both films are engaging narratives that take place during war times.
